content.raw:
In reference to [Issue #196](#!/osrf/subt/issues/196/update-qual_cloudsim-instructions), there is an inconsistency in the documentation for the scoring behavior.

‌

According to Section 11.3 of the [SubT Challenge Tunnel Circuit Rules Document](https://www.subtchallenge.com/resources/SubT_Challenge_Tunnel_Rules.pdf):

_For the Tunnel Circuit, the total number of artifacts is 20 and the total number of allowed scored reports is 40. Once an artifact has been successfully reported, any duplicate reports will be considered invalid and will count against the total number of reports._

But according to the [API Documentation](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api):

_Repeated artifact requests \(a request is considered repeated when contains the same artifact type and position as a previously sent request\) do not count as new requests for scoring purposes. In other words, a team will not lose an extra token while retrying to send a previously reported artifact._
content.html:
In reference to Issue #196, there is an inconsistency in the documentation for the scoring behavior.

‌

According to Section 11.3 of the SubT Challenge Tunnel Circuit Rules Document:

For the Tunnel Circuit, the total number of artifacts is 20 and the total number of allowed scored reports is 40. Once an artifact has been successfully reported, any duplicate reports will be considered invalid and will count against the total number of reports.

But according to the API Documentation:

Repeated artifact requests (a request is considered repeated when contains the same artifact type and position as a previously sent request) do not count as new requests for scoring purposes. In other words, a team will not lose an extra token while retrying to send a previously reported artifact.

I run 3 simulations \(robotika, \[ver4, ver5, ver6\], Simple Tunnel 02\) last night and today. Just to be sure that everything is initialized \(see 6 minutes issue #202\) I added extra pure ROS code originally waiting for all necessary topics, which are later used in the main navigation program. They all first print “begin” and at the end “end” to ROS info. The last simulation \(ver6, cab6fd44-2448-4fa7-bd38-a44d94250182\) even failed to pass “Wait for /X2/front/image\_raw/compressed” :frowning2: 

Code snippet:

```python
def wait_for(topic, topic_type):
    rospy.loginfo('Wait for ' + topic)
    rospy.wait_for_message(topic, topic_type)
    rospy.loginfo('Done with ' + topic)


def wait_for_sensors():
    rospy.init_node('mdwait', anonymous=True)
    wait_for_master()
    rospy.loginfo('-------------- mdwait BEGIN --------------')
    wait_for('/X2/imu/data', Imu)
    wait_for('/X2/front_scan', LaserScan)

```

values.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw:
Simple Tunnel 2 runs at about 2x realtime in the cloud.  This would be fine if the control loop also ran 2x faster, but the control loop runs 10x slower in the cloud than on my local computer.  With this large of a differential the control loop fails in cloudsim.

I will run an experiment where I try and maximally slow down the cloudsim \(with lots of vehicles\) and speed up my control loop to see if the differential can be reduced.

My current situation is that I can score locally using run\_docker\_compose.sh, but running successfully using cloudsim through the portal is not possible due to the performance issues.
content.html:
Simple Tunnel 2 runs at about 2x realtime in the cloud. This would be fine if the control loop also ran 2x faster, but the control loop runs 10x slower in the cloud than on my local computer. With this large of a differential the control loop fails in cloudsim.

I will run an experiment where I try and maximally slow down the cloudsim (with lots of vehicles) and speed up my control loop to see if the differential can be reduced.

My current situation is that I can score locally using run_docker_compose.sh, but running successfully using cloudsim through the portal is not possible due to the performance issues.

content.raw: We are trying to test our solution in the different environments, but are having issues with what we think is the bridge failing for tunnel\_circuit\_practice\_02 and simple\_tunnel\_02. All environments work fine if we run our solution locally with the virtual testbed, but fails in docker compose or local cloudsim environments because nothing is published to the robot points topic. It does work in all environments with tunnel\_circuit\_practice\_01 though.

It does work in all environments with tunnel_circuit_practice_01 though.

values.title: Control response for X3 different in cloud than locally

content.raw:
There appears to be a dependency of the control response for the x3 vehicle based on the real-time rate of the simulation.  In particular, a linear z input of 16.88 results in a relatively fast lift-off of the vehicle when the simulation runs in near real-time.  When running in the cloud at 1/8th of real time an x3 vehicle won’t even take off with a linear z input of 16.88.  Similarly, when the cloud is running at 2x realtime it appears to be much more sensitive to the inputs.  

There may be a different root cause, but in any case the same control input results in different behaviors in the cloud than locally.

To reproduce: publish a linear z input of 16.88 to the x3 vehicle on a local simulation run and then to a cloud run with a low real time rate \(with multiple vehicles simulated\)

‌
content.html:
There appears to be a dependency of the control response for the x3 vehicle based on the real-time rate of the simulation. In particular, a linear z input of 16.88 results in a relatively fast lift-off of the vehicle when the simulation runs in near real-time. When running in the cloud at 1/8th of real time an x3 vehicle won’t even take off with a linear z input of 16.88. Similarly, when the cloud is running at 2x realtime it appears to be much more sensitive to the inputs.

There may be a different root cause, but in any case the same control input results in different behaviors in the cloud than locally.

To reproduce: publish a linear z input of 16.88 to the x3 vehicle on a local simulation run and then to a cloud run with a low real time rate (with multiple vehicles simulated)

‌

content.raw:
I noticed for tunnel\_circuit\_practice\_02 that the artifact origin defined in the tunnel\_circuit\_practice\_02\_gz.world file and the reported artifact origin offset from the /subt/pose\_from\_artifact\_origin seem inconsistent. 

At start, the service returns 

> ORIGIN OFFSET: header:  
> seq: 0  
> stamp: 10.732000000  
> frame\_id: artifact\_origin  
> pose:  
> position:  
> x: -6  
> y: 5  
> z: 0.0614999  
> orientation:  
> x: -5.61681e-11  
> y: 1.16108e-08  
> z: -6.95367e-18  
> w: 1

While the artifact origin in the world file is defined as 

```
<include>
  <name>artifact_origin</name>
  <pose>2 4 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
  <uri>model://fiducial</uri>
</include>
```

‌

The position offset is the same as I receive for other tunnels, such as simple\_tunnel\_02, which has an artifact origin of 10,0,0. If the world artifact origin is set at a different location, should not the artifact origin pose be different?  Could this potentially affect scoring?
content.html:

content.raw:
Ignition seems to be experiencing some sort of freeze event where the clock randomly stops publishing for upwards of 20 seconds or more at a time. I’ve tested this with local catkin and local cloudsim in simple\_tunnel\_02 and both experience it. It may happen right at the start, or after it’s been running for a period of time, or not at all.

A snippet of the clock output via “rostopic echo /clock”:  

> clock:  
> secs: 89  
> nsecs: 504000000
>
> clock:  
> secs: 89  
> nsecs: 508000000
>
> clock:  
> secs: 89  
> nsecs: 512000000
>
> clock:  
> secs: 165  
> nsecs: 928000000
>
> clock:  
> secs: 165  
> nsecs: 932000000
>
> clock:  
> secs: 165  
> nsecs: 936000000

I’m not seeing any error messages from the ignition or bridge consoles, the SubT Simulator window is still responsive, but the realtime factor doesn’t change for the duration of the freeze \(normally it’s constantly changing\).  All of our solution nodes stop responding as well, without error, until the clock starts again after which we get a lot of errors related to time jumping into the future. If I run long enough, it may happen multiple times.

‌

content.raw:
We recognized after a test run on our local docker container, that we were able to report an Artifact although the base\_station was not in the neighbors list! 

A Robot was standing on the staging area all the time and did get the base\_station in the neighbors list not before the reporting of the first artifact which was done at 117 seconds simulation time. 

If this occurs only at the beginning of the simulation, we can live with it. But if this will also occur late on, the neighbors list cannot be used and is misleading!
content.html:
We recognized after a test run on our local docker container, that we were able to report an Artifact although the base_station was not in the neighbors list!

A Robot was standing on the staging area all the time and did get the base_station in the neighbors list not before the reporting of the first artifact which was done at 117 seconds simulation time.

If this occurs only at the beginning of the simulation, we can live with it. But if this will also occur late on, the neighbors list cannot be used and is misleading!

values.title: [Urban Feature] Upload Simulation - use existing former Simulation as basis

content.raw:
Could it be possible to add a functionality to the upload Simulation, where an existing simulation can be used as the basis. The reloaded parameters could then be changed \(e.g. by only changeing the circuit/tunnel parameter\). A button could be added in the list of the existing simulation to open a new upload Simulation dialog with these parameters.

I know that it is really late, but if this would be possible it would be really helpful. It would reduce the risk that the final solution is uploaded with faulty parameters \(e.g. a wrong robotname\).

try10e - tunnel\_circuit\_practice\_01 - drone fails to lift off

values.title: RGBD Sensor Range longer than specification

content.raw:
The range of the depth portion of the RGBD sensor is longer than the range documented at [#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api)

This is possible to miss as it is not on [#!/osrf/subt/wiki/robots](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/robots)

I think it had been 10 meters in gazebo \(which was reasonable as the kinect 2 has an 8 or 10 meters range but ~5m with skeletal tracking\).  I am not sure what it was in the earlier versions of ignition.  The latest version has a much longer range.

This applies at least to X3 config 4, but possibly to other RGBD sensors as well.

‌

‌

content.raw: Cloudsim is not functioning well enough to run tests.  Of my three overnight runs, one is pending after 10 hours, one failed in admin review after 10 hours \(had been in launching pods for many an hour\) and the last generated files, but there were multiple problems with the simulation \(I will submit a separate issue for that\).  Others seem to be having similar problems.
content.html: Cloudsim is not functioning well enough to run tests. Of my three overnight runs, one is pending after 10 hours, one failed in admin review after 10 hours (had been in launching pods for many an hour) and the last generated files, but there were multiple problems with the simulation (I will submit a separate issue for that). Others seem to be having similar problems.

First off I’m embarrassed to be posting this on the day of the submission deadline. I’ve mostly been focusing development efforts on a single robot at a time, and am just now trying to put everything together.

I’ve been having issues receiving messages from other robots via the subt_communication_client. Running locally without the cloudsim infrastructure, I did a bunch of digging and found that the subt_communication_broker is now using an ign service call (not ros) to send the message to the destination:

          if (!this->node.Request(client.address, msg))
          {
            std::cerr << "[CommsBrokerPlugin::DispatchMessages()]: Error "
                      << "sending message to [" << client.address << "]"
                      << std::endl;
          }

So I was able to get communication working again, without the cloudsim infrastructure, by setting _useIgnition=truein the subt_communication_client. Note though that this is exactly what the documentation says not to do:

    /// \param[in] _useIgnition Set to true if you are using Ignition
    /// transport (i.e. not ROS). This is needed by the base station,
    /// and tests. If you are a regular robot, then you really really do not
    /// want to set this to true as your Commsclient will not work.

This allows the robots to communicate without cloudsim, but then if I run the cloudsim docker-compose infrastructure locally, I’m back to the robots not being able to communicate at all. I’ve tried _useIgnition=false, _useIgnition=true, etc… but nothing so far has worked. I will try this on the cloudsim portal as well but was hoping to debug any remaining comm issues locally first.

When the comms is not working, client->Neighbors() always returns an empty list (despite client->StartBeaconInterval having been called) and sending a message to “broadcast” has no effect (not received by itself or another robot, despite close proximity).

Does anyone have any thoughts on this? Thanks!

content.raw:
The data for this run can be see in the try15c run.  The issues seen:

1.  Cloudsim did not respond to vehicle commands for 20 seconds.  Vehicle turn was commanded at sim time 67, but did not start turning until sim time 84.
2. Cloudsim did not provide consistent imu data until sim time 299.  It looks like one message came through early and no more imu messages until time 299.
3. Cloudsim imu data dropped out at time 362 and no futher imu data was available for the run.
4. Ground truth data dropped out intermittently while in the start area  - 873 to 907 for example

These were the issues for the first vehicle.  It looks like when there are multiple vehicles there is a high probability of maybe ignition bridge problems.

‌

values.title: Add version numbers to docker images allowing for regression testing

content.raw:
At docker hub, the images should have version numbers and each and every published image should be available to download to allow for regression testing \(something works with one version and does not work with other\).

In addition, it would be best if the cloud environment allowed selecting an explicit version of the docker images to run against. Again this will help tremendously to debug what is wrong, which in turn will help us create a more specific issues here that can be actionable instead of just saying “it does not work”.

This is a followup to [https://community.subtchallenge.com/t/cloudsim-version-numbering-and-staging-releases/1147](https://community.subtchallenge.com/t/cloudsim-version-numbering-and-staging-releases/1147) where Tim Chung stated during the Virtual Tunnel award ceremony, that is should be implemented.
content.html:
At docker hub, the images should have version numbers and each and every published image should be available to download to allow for regression testing (something works with one version and does not work with other).

In addition, it would be best if the cloud environment allowed selecting an explicit version of the docker images to run against. Again this will help tremendously to debug what is wrong, which in turn will help us create a more specific issues here that can be actionable instead of just saying “it does not work”.

This is a followup to https://community.subtchallenge.com/t/cloudsim-version-numbering-and-staging-releases/1147 where Tim Chung stated during the Virtual Tunnel award ceremony, that is should be implemented.

values.title: Deterministic simulation, lockstep run of simulation and controllers

content.raw:
Our controller is strictly deterministic. When we have our binary log file we can replay what it did and get the exact same results \(verified against the log\). However the simulation environment is not deterministic which adds yet another challenge. The amount of non-determinism is significant to the point that it affects the final score. Take the final leaderboard for Tunnel Circuit from here: [https://www.darpa.mil/news-events/2019-10-30](https://www.darpa.mil/news-events/2019-10-30). Only on worlds B and E we got the expected score distribution.

One steps towards being able to create and run deterministic tests would be the creation of something called lockstep mode where the simulation and the controller wait for each other. The [PX4 team implemented this for gazebo 9](https://dev.px4.io/master/en/simulation/#lockstep-simulation) and made it the default for their tests. There are many advantages to this:

* the results of the tests no longer depend on the speed of the computer running them or on the processes scheduler
* when you attach debugger to the controller and step over your code, the simulation will wait so when you decide to continue, everything works just the same as if you never stopped the execution

My proposal is to implement this at least for local runs to ease development. Even better would be to implement this for the cloud simulation as well. This way we could side step the troubles with the speed of the AWS machines and make those runs deterministic as well.
content.html:
Our controller is strictly deterministic. When we have our binary log file we can replay what it did and get the exact same results (verified against the log). However the simulation environment is not deterministic which adds yet another challenge. The amount of non-determinism is significant to the point that it affects the final score. Take the final leaderboard for Tunnel Circuit from here: https://www.darpa.mil/news-events/2019-10-30. Only on worlds B and E we got the expected score distribution.

One steps towards being able to create and run deterministic tests would be the creation of something called lockstep mode where the simulation and the controller wait for each other. The PX4 team implemented this for gazebo 9 and made it the default for their tests. There are many advantages to this:

  • the results of the tests no longer depend on the speed of the computer running them or on the processes scheduler
  • when you attach debugger to the controller and step over your code, the simulation will wait so when you decide to continue, everything works just the same as if you never stopped the execution

My proposal is to implement this at least for local runs to ease development. Even better would be to implement this for the cloud simulation as well. This way we could side step the troubles with the speed of the AWS machines and make those runs deterministic as well.

content.raw:
The World B \(Robotika runs 04, 05, 06\) was the worse as it looks like the topics were sometimes available sometimes not. This issue is similar to #261, but the topis re-appeared once a while.

‌

```
1666.772000000 INFO /subt_solution [/home/developer/subt_solution/src/subt_seed/src/subt_seed_node.cc:403(getSpeedCmd)] [topics: ] Python3: stdout 1:05:00.179489 (-719.3 1010.2 0.0) [('image', 268)]
1668.172000000 INFO /subt_solution [/home/developer/subt_solution/src/subt_seed/src/subt_seed_node.cc:94(imageCallback)] [topics: ] received Image 2000
3679.684000000 INFO /subt_solution [/home/developer/subt_solution/src/subt_seed/src/subt_seed_node.cc:94(imageCallback)] [topics: ] received Image 2100
3679.684000000 INFO /subt_solution [/home/developer/subt_solution/src/subt_seed/src/subt_seed_node.cc:94(imageCallback)] [topics: ] received Image 2200
```

I understand the `odom `and the `imu/data` messages so that the robots are placed in the world directed/looking along the x-axis. This is the case in all 3 simple\_urban worlds. In all the tunnel worlds we did not have that problem. 

For the existing solutions from the tunnel circuit it would be the easiest to still use the unwritten condition, that the tunnel entrance is directed in x-axis- direction.

values.title: Future enhancement: Droppable communications repeater nodes

content.raw:
As a future enhancement \(not necessarily for Urban Circuit since this is probably a larger change\), I would like to suggest we have robots capable of carrying dropping nodes, where each node is capable of relaying messages and similar communications-related functionality. This is a capability which would be possible in the real world, so it would be nice to enable it for the virtual track as well. 

These communications nodes could potentially help extend communications distances and store information \(warning messages, mapping data, …\) to help peer robots which are out of range.

I believe there are a couple options for how this could work:

**1\) Competitor-defined nodes**

Each communications node could be defined similarly to a robot. No locomotion/actuators/sensors would be necessary. The node would have 2 states: `carried` and `dropped`. It would be somehow tied to a parent robot \(e.g. maybe by name – COMM1X1 could be a comm node carried by a robot named X1\). An ROS service could be used to change the state from `carried` to `dropped`. Upon entering the dropped state, the node position would no longer be tied to the parent robot, and normal physics rules would apply.

This option would allow the competitors to write custom controller code for the node, and it would be subject to the same limitations as other robots \(operating on its own isolated VM, limited by communication distances, etc…\). The node would, however, only be capable of communications and data processing related functionality due to its lack of sensors and actuation.

**2\) Predefined nodes**

In this case, each communications node could be defined similarly to a sensor/actuator. It would run predefined code capable of some functions such as repeating a message to another destination and/or queryable data storage. A robot could carry several of these nodes, as defined by its sensor configuration. Again, an ROS service could be used to change the state from `carried` to `dropped`, at which point it would no longer be tied to its parent robot, and normal physics rules would apply.

These communications nodes could potentially help extend communications distances and store information (warning messages, mapping data, …) to help peer robots which are out of range.

I believe there are a couple options for how this could work:

1) Competitor-defined nodes

Each communications node could be defined similarly to a robot. No locomotion/actuators/sensors would be necessary. The node would have 2 states: carried and dropped. It would be somehow tied to a parent robot (e.g. maybe by name – COMM1X1 could be a comm node carried by a robot named X1). An ROS service could be used to change the state from carried to dropped. Upon entering the dropped state, the node position would no longer be tied to the parent robot, and normal physics rules would apply.

This option would allow the competitors to write custom controller code for the node, and it would be subject to the same limitations as other robots (operating on its own isolated VM, limited by communication distances, etc…). The node would, however, only be capable of communications and data processing related functionality due to its lack of sensors and actuation.

2) Predefined nodes

In this case, each communications node could be defined similarly to a sensor/actuator. A robot could carry several of these nodes, as defined by its sensor configuration. Again, an ROS service could be used to change the state from carried to dropped, at which point it would no longer be tied to its parent robot, and normal physics rules would apply.

content.raw:
This is related to [#!/osrf/subt/issues/97/potential-issue-with-x3-x4-control-via](#!/osrf/subt/issues/97/potential-issue-with-x3-x4-control-via) and [#!/osrf/subt/issues/163/any-help-on-how-to-fly-uavs-inside-tunnel](#!/osrf/subt/issues/163/any-help-on-how-to-fly-uavs-inside-tunnel)

When applying a static upward force to the X4/X3 drones, I have noticed that drones will drift forward slowly.   I am wondering why they do not hover in place.  This leads me to a few other questions about the controls.

* What is the future plan for the UAV  control?  Is cmd\_force going to be the permanent method, will it be reverting back to the waypoint method eventually, or will it change to something else in the future?
* Is the cmd\_force being applied to the center of mass of the UAV, and the current controller adjust motor speeds as necessary?
* If the requested applied force is in the x direction, will the current controller adjust for any rotations of the drone, or do we need to account for that in our control model? 
* Is there a method for us to control motor speeds directly, if not, can that be opened up?

‌

‌
content.html:
This is related to #!/osrf/subt/issues/97/potential-issue-with-x3-x4-control-via and #!/osrf/subt/issues/163/any-help-on-how-to-fly-uavs-inside-tunnel

When applying a static upward force to the X4/X3 drones, I have noticed that drones will drift forward slowly. I am wondering why they do not hover in place. This leads me to a few other questions about the controls.

  • What is the future plan for the UAV control? Is cmd_force going to be the permanent method, will it be reverting back to the waypoint method eventually, or will it change to something else in the future?
  • Is the cmd_force being applied to the center of mass of the UAV, and the current controller adjust motor speeds as necessary?
  • If the requested applied force is in the x direction, will the current controller adjust for any rotations of the drone, or do we need to account for that in our control model?
  • Is there a method for us to control motor speeds directly, if not, can that be opened up?

content.raw:
Today is the deadline for the user model submission via pull-request for Urban Circuit, so this post is rather proposal for the next challenge.

The process adding new configuration is rather complex - here I would like to thank @{557058:14b7fd50-d65a-47a8-825c-fa89681d07bd}  for his help with our \("robotika"\) pull request \(it is not over yet\). Actually all we wanted to do is to replace original HD camera in X2 config 4 \(with lidar 30m\) by RGBD in order to see small obstacles in front of the robot and distinguish ramps from obstacles. The PR is mainly copy & paste of parts we do not really understand \(unfortunately there was no working example to start with, but this will surely change for Cave Circuit\). Also we should not really get the attribution \(#284\), unless you count this process :wink:. Note, we gave up to repeat this process for X1 which could be more suitable for the subway environment \(rails\).

So that was the motivation - question is if this can be simplified? In particular if you are building configuration only from existing  
components \(robot and sensors\) and you only "mount" them together. The complex process can be reserved for new/non-existing robots and sensors. The configuration would be then like "shopping list" where you could choose from sensors and only specify placement. There could be even just few "mounting positions" like front, left, rear ... or just \(x y z yaw pitch roll\). There is no need to copy materials, worlds, models etc. This list would be input for “generator” which could create the complex configuration if that is the only way - or it could create it “on demand” during start of the simulation. Is this feasible?
content.html:
Today is the deadline for the user model submission via pull-request for Urban Circuit, so this post is rather proposal for the next challenge.

The process adding new configuration is rather complex - here I would like to thank @Arthur Schang for his help with our ("robotika") pull request (it is not over yet). Actually all we wanted to do is to replace original HD camera in X2 config 4 (with lidar 30m) by RGBD in order to see small obstacles in front of the robot and distinguish ramps from obstacles. The PR is mainly copy & paste of parts we do not really understand (unfortunately there was no working example to start with, but this will surely change for Cave Circuit). Also we should not really get the attribution (#284), unless you count this process . Note, we gave up to repeat this process for X1 which could be more suitable for the subway environment (rails).

So that was the motivation - question is if this can be simplified? In particular if you are building configuration only from existing
components (robot and sensors) and you only "mount" them together. The complex process can be reserved for new/non-existing robots and sensors. The configuration would be then like "shopping list" where you could choose from sensors and only specify placement. There could be even just few "mounting positions" like front, left, rear ... or just (x y z yaw pitch roll). There is no need to copy materials, worlds, models etc. This list would be input for “generator” which could create the complex configuration if that is the only way - or it could create it “on demand” during start of the simulation. Is this feasible?

Our new config `sophisticated_engineering_x4_config_1` should be a copy of the `x4_config_5` robot with only changes in the lights cone angle and the camera position. During the review of the pull request, we were asked to make changes to the lights regarding the shadow parameters. Testing now the new config the lights cannot be allways seen. 

Tested with catkin Workspace:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/848103870-Bildschirmfoto_von_2019-12-17_22-10-14.png)

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2251174337-Bildschirmfoto_von_2019-12-17_22-18-14.png)
Does this have to do with the shadow parameter? Or is there anything else changed by mistake?

values.title: Running into "max depth exceeded" error with the current subt-virtual-testbed base image

content.raw:
This isn’t really a major problem, I can workaround it, but in the most recent `osrf/subt-virtual-testbed` base image, I am running into "max depth exceeded" errors in my own Dockerfiles. It seems the fs layer count of the `subt-virtual-testbed` image is very close to Docker’s maximum \(which appears to be around 127\). So when I add several additional fs layers, it runs into the limit.

Running `docker history osrf/subt-virtual-testbed:latest` I can see there are a lot of layers corresponding to `ign fuel download` commands.  These could probably be consolidated a bit more to avoid running close to this limit.

If anyone else runs into the same problem though, a fairly simple workaround is to run `docker-squash` on the `subt-virtual-testbed` image to flatten it before using it in my own files, something like:

```
sudo docker-squash osrf/subt-virtual-testbed:latest -t subt-virtual-testbed-flat:latest | docker load
```

‌
